comment_text.mn151:2.3: See MN 121:3.3 and note. This discourse offers a different perspective on this meditation.
comment_text.mn151:2.5: While the concept of a “great man” is familiar, the “meditation of a great man” (mahāpurisavihāra) appears only here and at Kd 22:2.5.10, which seems to borrow from this passage.
comment_text.mn151:3.3: Here the contemplation of the six sense fields is taught in the context of sense restraint through the active development of wisdom or discernment.
comment_text.mn151:9.1: The following sections may be a later addition, as they are absent from the parallel (SA 236 at T ii 57b24).
comment_text.mn151:20.6: Even the arahant continues to meditate and practice since it is a happy way to live, and to set a good example.
comment_text.mn151:21.4: This clarifies the overall purpose of the discourse, to set out a method for mendicants to reflect during their daily walk for almsfood, at which time they are likely to encounter distracting sights, sounds, and smells.

root_text.mn151:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
root_text.mn151:1.3: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn151:2.1: “Vippasannāni kho te, sāriputta, indriyāni, parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
root_text.mn151:2.2: Katamena kho tvaṁ, sāriputta, vihārena etarahi bahulaṁ viharasī”ti?
root_text.mn151:2.3: “Suññatāvihārena kho ahaṁ, bhante, etarahi bahulaṁ viharāmī”ti.
root_text.mn151:2.5: Mahāpurisavihārena kira tvaṁ, sāriputta, etarahi bahulaṁ viharasi.
root_text.mn151:3.2: ‘suññatāvihārena bahulaṁ vihareyyan’ti, tena, sāriputta, bhikkhunā iti paṭisañcikkhitabbaṁ:
root_text.mn151:3.3: ‘yena cāhaṁ maggena gāmaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisiṁ, yasmiñca padese piṇḍāya acariṁ, yena ca maggena gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamiṁ, atthi nu kho me tattha cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu chando vā rāgo vā doso vā moho vā paṭighaṁ vāpi cetaso’ti?
root_text.mn151:3.4: Sace, sāriputta, bhikkhu paccavekkhamāno evaṁ jānāti:

root_text.mn151:21.1: Ye hi keci, sāriputta, atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhesuṁ, sabbe te evameva paccavekkhitvā paccavekkhitvā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhesuṁ.
root_text.mn151:21.2: Yepi hi keci, sāriputta, anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhessanti, sabbe te evameva paccavekkhitvā paccavekkhitvā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhessanti.
root_text.mn151:21.3: Yepi hi keci, sāriputta, etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhenti, sabbe te evameva paccavekkhitvā paccavekkhitvā piṇḍapātaṁ parisodhenti.
root_text.mn151:21.7: Attamano āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn151:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn151:1.3: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
translation_text.mn151:2.1: “Sāriputta, your faculties are so very clear, and your complexion is pure and bright.
translation_text.mn151:2.2: What kind of meditation are you usually practicing these days?”
translation_text.mn151:2.3: “Sir, these days I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.”
translation_text.mn151:2.5: It seems you usually practice the meditation of a great man.
translation_text.mn151:2.6: For emptiness is the meditation of a great man.
translation_text.mn151:3.2: ‘May I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.’ So they should reflect:
translation_text.mn151:3.3: ‘Along the path that I went for alms, or in the place I wandered for alms, or along the path that I returned from alms, was there any desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in my heart for sights known by the eye?’
translation_text.mn151:3.4: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:3.5: there was such desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in their heart, they should make an effort to give up those unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:3.6: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:3.7: there was no such desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in their heart, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:4-8.2: ‘Along the path that I went for alms, or in the place I wandered for alms, or along the path that I returned from alms, was there any desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in my heart for sounds known by the ear …
translation_text.mn151:4-8.7: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:4-8.8: there was such desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in their heart, they should make an effort to give up those unskillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:4-8.9: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:4-8.10: there was no such desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion in their heart, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:9.2: ‘Have I given up the five kinds of sensual stimulation?’
translation_text.mn151:9.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:9.4: they have not given them up, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:9.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:9.6: they have given them up, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:10.2: ‘Have I given up the five hindrances?’
translation_text.mn151:10.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:10.4: they have not given them up, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:10.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:10.6: they have given them up, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:11.2: ‘Have I completely understood the five grasping aggregates?’
translation_text.mn151:11.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:11.4: they have not completely understood them, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:11.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:11.6: they have completely understood them, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:12.2: ‘Have I developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?’
translation_text.mn151:12.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:12.4: they haven’t developed them, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:12.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:12.6: they have developed them, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:13.2: ‘Have I developed the four right efforts …
translation_text.mn151:14.2: the four bases of psychic power …
translation_text.mn151:18.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:18.4: they haven’t developed it, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:18.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:18.6: they have developed it, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:19.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:19.4: they haven’t developed them, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:19.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:19.6: they have developed them, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:20.3: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:20.4: they haven’t realized them, they should make an effort to do so.
translation_text.mn151:20.5: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
translation_text.mn151:20.6: they have realized them, they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn151:21.1: Whether in the past, future, or present, all those who purify their almsfood do so by continually checking in this way.
translation_text.mn151:21.4: So, Sāriputta, you should all train like this: ‘We shall purify our almsfood by continually checking.’”
translation_text.mn151:21.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn151:21.7: Satisfied, Venerable Sāriputta approved what the Buddha said.
